paper_decoration.summary: Margins throughout the examined opening are decorated with the zerefşân (serpme) technique: fine gold particles sprinkled across the page margins, producing a warm golden tone against a cream/off-white paper ground. Individual gold particles are not resolved at the available screenshot resolution, but the warm margin tone is consistent with zerefşân application and is confirmed by the YEK catalogue entry. Gold and black ruling lines (altın cedvel) frame the text block. The catalogue also records an illuminated headpiece (başlığı tezhipli) not visible on the examined folio. The visual confirmation verdict is 'probable.'

key_indicators: Gold-sprinkled (zerefşân) margins: standard feature of Istanbul luxury manuscript production from the mid-16th century onwards
Gold and black cedvel ruling system (altın cedvel) consistent with Ottoman court ateliers
Naskh script with ta'lik / nestaʿlîk headings: characteristic of later Ottoman literary anthologies
Nuruosmaniye collection context: associated with Sultan III. Osman vakıf (d. 1757); most holdings are 16th–18th-century Ottoman commissions

The Mevlana anthology format is common across Anatolian, Azerbaijani, and Central Asian Ottoman-influenced contexts
No colophon data or explicit attribution is available from the examined folio; date range remains broad (16th–18th century)

paper_decoration.details: Both pages of the opening show margins with a warm golden tone consistent with gold-sprinkled treatment. The margins appear slightly warmer/more golden than the text area paper, suggesting zerefşân application. However, individual gold particles are not resolved at this resolution. The paper ground is a light cream color. Gold and black ruling lines frame the text block. The catalogue confirms: 'Sahife kenarları zerefşan tekniğiyle süslenmiştir.' The manuscript is noted to have an illuminated headpiece (başlığı tezhipli) which is not visible on this page opening. The text appears to be an anthology of Mevlana selections (İntihâb-ı Dîvân-ı Mevlânâ).

style_attribution.justification: Gold-sprinkled margins with gold cedvel are a standard feature across several centuries of Ottoman manuscript production. Without seeing the illuminated headpiece or having colophon data, the dating range remains broad. The Mevlana anthology content is consistent with Ottoman literary taste across a wide period.

folio_analyses.condition_notes: Paper appears in stable condition. Some overall yellowing/aging visible. No obvious damage, repairs, or losses visible in the screenshot.
folio_analyses.analysis_limitations: Image is a YEK viewer screenshot at moderate resolution (~1536 px width). The zerefşân is not individually resolved at particle level — the verdict is 'probable' based on the warm golden margin tone and catalogue confirmation. The illuminated headpiece mentioned in the catalogue is not visible on this folio; a separate examination of the headpiece pages would strengthen the analysis. YEK viewer chrome reduces effective image area.

bibliography.access_notes: Peer-reviewed journal article; available through JSTOR and institutional subscriptions.

bibliography.citation: Bloom, Jonathan M. Paper Before Print: The History and Impact of Paper in the Islamic World. New Haven: Yale University Press, 2001.
bibliography.relevance: Comprehensive history of paper in the Islamic world, including the development of decorated paper techniques and their spread through Ottoman and Persianate manuscript production.

provenance.donor: Nuruosmaniye Vakfı (waqf of Sultan III. Osman, r. 1754–1757)
provenance.notes: All Nuruosmaniye holdings bear the tuğralı vakıf mühürü (sultanic seal) of III. Osman. The collection was founded in 1755 with the completion of the Nuruosmaniye Mosque complex. Manuscripts were likely acquired or transferred from earlier Ottoman collections. The catalogue was compiled by Fatih Yıldız; catalogue descriptions for this collection are thorough regarding paper decoration.
